data.name: Ternary Operator in Scala!
data.description:
People learning Scala usually come across quite a surprise (I know I did): The fact that there is no ternary operator in Scala.

However, Scala also lets you get very "creative", which is one of the many reasons I fell in love with it. In fact, it **IS** possible to make the following line compile in Scala (assuming the existence of an `Int` `age`):

```
val booze = (age < 21) ? "Cranberry" | "Cosmo"
```

While it's not the traditional `?:` combination known to all, I'd call `?|` a close enough substitute.

So here is your task:
* First and foremost, make the above line of code compile.
* Secondly, you must evalute only the block that you need. That is to say, if the condition was `true`, you MUST NOT evaluate the `false` block, regardless of whether or not you return its value, and vice-versa.


The test file will import every top level element that you place in the `Ternary` `package`, by using the following import line:

`import Ternary._`

A Note on Tests:
Ternary Operators is also expected to work in nested blocks, like so:
`b1 ? (b2 ? 1 : 2) : 3`
where `b1` and `b2` are `Boolean`s
